test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the requirement for a company or proposed company in respect of which a Letter of Provisional Approval has been issued under subsection (4) to commence banking business?
test_cases.expected_output: A company or proposed company in respect of which a Letter of Provisional Approval has been issued under subsection (4) shall not commence banking business before the issue of a licence under section 5.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Can an agency, institution, person or body of persons which is a banking institution in terms of paragraph (b) or paragraph (d) of the definition of the expression "banking institution" in section 127 of the Monetary Law Act use the words "bank", "banker" or "banking" in its name?
test_cases.expected_output: Yes, an agency, institution, person or body of persons which is a banking institution in terms of paragraph (b) or paragraph (d) of the definition of the expression "banking institution" in section 127 of the Monetary Law Act can use the words "bank", "banker" or "banking" in its name.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the powers of the Governor of the Central Bank in relation to examining the books, accounts and records of a person suspected of carrying on banking business in contravention of the Act?
test_cases.expected_output: The Governor of the Central Bank has the power to direct the Director of Bank Supervision or any other officer of the Central Bank to examine the books, accounts and records of a person suspected of carrying on banking business in contravention of the Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Can a company be a subsidiary of another company if it has shares held or power exercisable by a person by virtue of the provisions of any debentures or trust deed?
test_cases.expected_output: No, shares held or power exercisable by a person by virtue of the provisions of any debentures or trust deed are disregarded when determining whether one company is a subsidiary of another.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the purpose of the Monetary Board's approval in relation to acquisitions and mergers under paragraph (c) of subsection (1) or paragraph (e) of subsection (1) of the Monetary Law Act?
test_cases.expected_output: The purpose of the Monetary Board's approval is to ensure that such acquisitions or mergers are in the interest of promoting a safe, sound, and stable banking system and fair competition in the banking industry.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the purpose of the exemption for a subsidiary of a licensed commercial bank or licensed specialised bank established in accordance with the provisions of the Act or any directions given hereunder?
test_cases.expected_output: The purpose of the exemption for a subsidiary of a licensed commercial bank or licensed specialised bank established in accordance with the provisions of the Act or any directions given hereunder is to allow such subsidiaries to carry on

test_cases.prompt: Question: Can a licensed commercial bank to whom notice has been issued under subsection (1) of section 13 of the Monetary Law Act tender objections in writing to the Monetary Board?
test_cases.expected_output: Yes, a licensed commercial bank to whom notice has been issued under subsection (1) of section 13 of the Monetary Law Act can, within thirty days of the date of such order, tender objections in writing to the Monetary Board giving reasons why such approval shall not be withdrawn or the terms and conditions varied.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Can a company be a subsidiary of another company if it has shares held or power exercisable by a nominee of the other company or its subsidiary?
test_cases.expected_output: Yes, a company can be a subsidiary of another company if it has shares held or power exercisable by a nominee of the other company or its subsidiary, unless the nominee is concerned only in a fiduciary capacity.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the offence committed by a person who submits false or misleading information in an application for a licence or in any other document submitted in connection therewith?
test_cases.expected_output: The offence committed by a person who submits false or misleading information in an application for a licence or in any other document submitted in connection therewith is an offence under this Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the terms and conditions that the Monetary Board may impose on a licence issued to a company or proposed company to carry on banking business in Sri Lanka?
test_cases.expected_output: The Monetary Board may impose terms and conditions on a licence issued to a company or proposed company to carry on banking business in Sri Lanka, including the type of banking business that may be carried on, the place or places or the area within which such banking business may be carried on, and any other terms and conditions that the Monetary Board may deem necessary.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Can the Monetary Board issue a licence under section 5 to a company that has not complied with the conditions stipulated in the Letter of Provisional Approval?
test_cases.expected_output: No, the Monetary Board may withdraw a Letter of Provisional Approval or refrain from issuing a licence under section 5 if the company or proposed company has not complied with the

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the duration for which a determination made by the Monetary Board under section 4(2) applies to companies and bodies corporate incorporated outside Sri Lanka?
test_cases.expected_output: A determination made by the Monetary Board under section 4(2) applies to companies and bodies corporate incorporated outside Sri Lanka for a period of six months from the date of the last of such determinations.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Are shares held or power exercisable by a company in a fiduciary capacity considered when determining whether one company is a subsidiary of another?
test_cases.expected_output: No, shares held or power exercisable by a company in a fiduciary capacity are not considered when determining whether one company is a subsidiary of another.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Who informs a licensed commercial bank of the amount payable as license fee and the manner in which such fee shall be paid?
test_cases.expected_output: The Monetary Board informs each licensed commercial bank of the amount payable as license fee and the manner in which such fee shall be paid.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the restrictions on a licensed commercial bank's acquisition or holding of shares in any company, as per the Act?
test_cases.expected_output: A licensed commercial bank shall not acquire or hold shares in any company other than a listed public company, and the aggregate amount invested in the shares of listed public companies shall not exceed a specified percentage of its capital funds.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Can a licensed commercial bank appeal against a decision of the Monetary Board to impose conditions on the withdrawal of the notice given under subsection (1) or to cancel its license?
test_cases.expected_output: Yes, a licensed commercial bank aggrieved by a decision of the Monetary Board made under subsection (3) to impose conditions on the withdrawal of the notice given under subsection (1) or to cancel its license, may within fourteen days of the date of receipt of the notification given under that subsection, appeal against such decision to the Court of Appeal.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Can the Monetary Board grant approval for an acquisition or merger under section 12 of the Monetary Law Act subject to terms and conditions?
test_cases.expected_output: Yes, the Monetary Board can grant approval for an acquisition or merger under section 12 of the Monetary Law Act subject to terms and conditions as may be specified by the Monetary Board with the concurrence of the Minister.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What must every advertisement, prospectus, notice or other publication issued by the company or proposed company before the issue of the licence specify?
test_cases.expected_output: Every advertisement, prospectus, notice or other publication issued by the company or proposed company before the issue of the licence shall be required to specify that it has not been issued a licence to carry on banking business under this Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Can a licence be issued under section 5 to a company formed and incorporated under the Companies Act No. 17 of 1982 unless certain conditions are met?
test_cases.expected_output: No, a licence shall not be issued under section 5 to a company formed and incorporated under the Companies Act No. 17 of 1982 unless (a) the company is a public company, (b) the Memorandum of Association of the company sets out as its primary object the carrying on of banking business as defined in this Act, and (c) the Memorandum of Association of the company restricts the other forms of business the company may carry on, if any, to any or all of the forms of business specified in Schedule II to this Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the grounds on which the Monetary Board may withdraw a Letter of Provisional Approval or refrain from issuing a licence under section 5?
test_cases.expected_output: The Monetary Board may withdraw a Letter of Provisional Approval or refrain from issuing a licence under section 5 on any of the following grounds: (a) the Monetary Board is not satisfied with the suitability of the company or proposed company, (b) the company or proposed company has not complied with the conditions stipulated in the Letter of Provisional Approval, (c) the company or proposed company has not complied with the requirements under this Act for the issue of a licence, (d) any information contained in the application for a licence or any information submitted in connection therewith by the company or proposed company is found to be false or incorrect, or (e) there has been a sufficiently significant change in the economic and banking environment of the country that warrants the suspension of the issue of licence under section 5.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Are shares held or power exercisable by a subsidiary of a company considered when determining whether one company is a subsidiary of another?
test_cases.expected_output: Yes, shares held or power exercisable by a subsidiary of a company are considered when determining whether one company is a subsidiary of another.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What happens after the expiration of sixty days from the date of the notice issued under subsection (1) of section 13 of the Monetary Law Act?
test_cases.expected_output: After the expiration of sixty days from the date of the notice issued under subsection (1) of section 13 of the Monetary Law Act, the Monetary Board shall, with the approval of the Minister, consider the objections placed before the Board under subsection (2) and either cancel the notice of withdrawal or variation unconditionally or confirm the withdrawal or variation with or without modification by order made in writing and published in the Gazette.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the purpose of the Monetary Board's power to withdraw or vary the terms and conditions of an approval granted under section 12 of the Monetary Law Act?
test_cases.expected_output: The purpose of the Monetary Board's power to withdraw or vary the terms and conditions of an approval granted under section 12 of the Monetary Law

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the exceptions to the restrictions on a licensed commercial bank's acquisition or holding of shares, as per the Act?
test_cases.expected_output: The restrictions do not apply to investments in a subsidiary company of the bank, investments in any other subsidiary company of the bank acquired with the approval of the Monetary Board, any shareholding which the bank might acquire in the course of the satisfaction of any debt due to such bank, or as a consequence of the underwriting of a share issue.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Is the Bank of Ceylon or the People’s Bank restricted by the preceding provisions in the exercise of their powers?
test_cases.expected_output: No, the Bank of Ceylon and the People’s Bank are not restricted by the preceding provisions in the exercise of their powers conferred on each such bank by and under the aforesaid statutes applicable to each of such banks, respectively.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Can the Monetary Board withdraw or vary the terms and conditions of an approval granted under section 12 of the Monetary Law Act?
test_cases.expected_output: Yes, the Monetary Board can, with the approval of the Minister, on a report by the Director of Bank Supervision, by order made in writing, withdraw the approval or vary the terms and conditions of an approval granted under section 12, including the closure of a branch, agency, or office of a licensed commercial bank.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the purpose of issuing a licence to a company or proposed company to carry on banking business in Sri Lanka?
test_cases.expected_output: The purpose of issuing a licence to a company or proposed company to carry on banking business in Sri Lanka is to authorize the company to carry on banking business in Sri Lanka subject to such terms and conditions as may be imposed by the Monetary Board.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the purpose of requiring a licensed commercial bank to hand over all books, records, and assets to the Director of Bank Supervision under section 11(b) of the Banking Act?
test_cases.expected_output: The purpose of requiring a licensed commercial bank to hand over all books, records, and assets to the Director of Bank Supervision under section 11(b) of the Banking Act is to enable the Monetary Board to exercise its powers under section 11(f) of the Banking Act, such as assuming control of the bank's business or vesting the bank's business in another licensed commercial bank.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the purpose of requiring a company or body corporate incorporated outside Sri Lanka to remit a sum of money to Sri Lanka before commencing business in Sri Lanka?
test_cases.expected_output: The purpose of requiring a company or body corporate incorporated outside Sri Lanka to remit a sum of money to Sri Lanka before commencing business in Sri Lanka is to ensure that the company has sufficient funds to carry on its business in Sri Lanka and to comply with the provisions of the Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Can a trade union registered under the Trade Union Ordinance (Chapter 138) use the words "bank", "banker" or "banking" in its name?
test_cases.expected_output: Yes, a trade union registered under the Trade Union Ordinance (Chapter 138) which is an association or combination of workers who are employees of a banking institution within the meaning of section 127 of the Monetary Law Act, or of the Central Bank or of a licensed specialised bank, can use the words "bank", "banker" or "banking" in its name.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Are shares held or power exercisable by a nominee for a company considered when determining whether one company is a subsidiary of another?
test_cases.expected_output: Yes, shares held or power exercisable by a nominee for a company are considered when determining whether one company is a subsidiary of another, unless the nominee is concerned only in a fiduciary capacity.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the conditions for a licensed commercial bank or licensed specialised bank incorporated or established outside Sri Lanka to use the words 'bank', 'banker', or 'banking' in its name?
test_cases.expected_output: A licensed commercial bank or licensed specialised bank incorporated or established outside Sri Lanka can use the words 'bank', 'banker', or 'banking' in its name, subject to the approval of the Monetary Board, as per section 16(1) of the Monetary Law Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the consequences for a licensed commercial bank that fails to comply with the Monetary Board's directions under section 10(1) in Sri Lanka?
test_cases.expected_output: If a licensed commercial bank fails to comply with the Monetary Board's directions under section 10(1) in Sri Lanka, the Monetary Board may further direct the bank to suspend its business within Sri Lanka and take charge of its books, records, and assets.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the consequences imposed by the Monetary Board on a licensed commercial bank under Section 11 of the Banking Act when measures are taken?
test_cases.expected_output: The consequences include suspension of business, restructuring, or vesting of the bank's business in another licensed commercial bank.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What dual purpose does the Monetary Board's determination of remittance serve, in relation to the national economy and company's suitability?
test_cases.expected_output: The Monetary Board's determination of remittance serves a dual purpose by ensuring the company's financial standing and ability to cover all obligations and liabilities incurred in the conduct of business in Sri Lanka, while also considering the interests of the national economy, including banking needs.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the exceptions to the rule that a licensed commercial bank cannot have a subsidiary that is not a licensed commercial bank, and how does the Monetary Board's opinion play a role in determining these exceptions?
test_cases.expected_output: The exceptions to this rule include subsidiaries that provide training in subjects related to banking, engage in hire purchase transactions, provide medium and long-term credit for development, engage in factory leasing and warehousing, provide management consultancy services, are a result of the bank acquiring shares of a company as a result of capitalizing interest accrued on loans granted by the bank, or carry on any form of business that, in the opinion of the Monetary Board, is not inconsistent with the business of banking and the provision of finance. The Monetary Board's opinion plays a crucial role in determining these exceptions, as they have the authority to grant written permission for a bank to have a subsidiary that carries on any form of business that they deem not inconsistent with the business of banking and the provision of finance.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the threshold of ownership that defines a 'material interest' in a licensed commercial bank in Sri Lanka, and how does it relate to the Monetary Board's approval process?
test_cases.expected_output: A 'material interest' in a licensed commercial bank in Sri Lanka refers to the holding of over ten percentum of the issued capital of the bank carrying voting rights. This threshold is significant in the context of the Monetary Board's approval process for acquisitions or mergers involving commercial banks, as the Board must grant approval prior to any such transaction, and will consider factors such as the promotion of a safe, sound, and stable banking system, and the individual or corporate body's fitness and propriety to hold a material interest in the bank.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the meaning of 'acting in concert' in the context of acquiring a material interest in a licensed commercial bank as per the Monetary Law Act?
test_cases.expected_output: Acting in concert means acting pursuant to an understanding (whether formal or informal) to actively cooperate in acquiring a material interest in a licensed commercial bank so as to obtain or consolidate control of that bank.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the dual role of plant roots in terms of soil nutrients and stability?
test_cases.expected_output: Plant roots serve a dual purpose by absorbing water and nutrients from the soil, which is vital for the plant's growth, and providing stability by anchoring the plant in the ground.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What exceptions exist for the use of banking-related names and descriptions in Sri Lanka, considering the role of the Monetary Board and licensed commercial banks?
test_cases.expected_output: There are exceptions, such as the use by licensed commercial banks or licensed specialised banks incorporated outside Sri Lanka that do not include 'bank,' 'banker,' or 'banking' in their names, and the use by subsidiaries, associations, trade unions, and agencies of licensed commercial banks or licensed specialised banks. Additionally, the representative office of a licensed commercial bank or licensed specialised bank incorporated or established outside Sri Lanka is also exempt.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What information must be included in an application for approval of a commercial bank's acquisition, merger, or consolidation under Sri Lanka's banking laws?
test_cases.expected_output: An application for approval of an acquisition or merger or consolidation under paragraph (c) or (e) of subsection (1) of section 12 must include a statement of the nature of the acquisition or merger or consolidation, as the case may be.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the consequences for a licensed commercial bank if it fails to comply with the provisions of Part III of the Act?
test_cases.expected_output: A licensed commercial bank that fails to comply with the provisions of Part III of the Act may face consequences such as not being able to commence or carry on business in Sri Lanka, and may also be subject to penalties or other disciplinary action as determined by the Monetary Board and the Minister.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Who is responsible for sending a copy of the Letter of Provisional Approval to the Registrar of Companies, and under what circumstances can the period of validity of such Letter be extended?
test_cases.expected_output: The Monetary Board is responsible for sending a copy of each Letter of Provisional Approval issued under subsection (4) and of any communication extending the period of validity of such Letter under subsection (5), or any withdrawal in terms of subsection (7), to the Registrar of Companies. The period of validity of the Letter of Provisional Approval shall not exceed 12 months from the date of issue and may only be extended by the Monetary Board in writing, in exceptional circumstances.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Under what circumstances can the Director of Bank Supervision take control of a licensed commercial bank's assets and business?
test_cases.expected_output: The Director of Bank Supervision can take control of a licensed commercial bank's assets and business if the bank fails to comply with the Monetary Board's directions issued under subsection (2) of section 10.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the dual role of the Director of Bank Supervision regarding banking business without a license?
test_cases.expected_output: The Director of Bank Supervision has the duty to examine the books, accounts, and records of suspected persons or banks carrying on banking business without a license and to direct them to furnish information and produce relevant documents, and failure to comply is prima facie evidence of carrying on banking business without a license.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the conditions that must be met for an individual, partnership, or corporate body to acquire a material interest in a licensed commercial bank in Sri Lanka?
test_cases.expected_output: An individual, partnership, or corporate body cannot acquire a material interest in a licensed commercial bank in Sri Lanka without the prior written approval of the Monetary Board given with the concurrence of the Minister. The Monetary Board may grant approval subject to terms and conditions and consider factors such as the promotion of a safe, sound, and stable banking system and the individual or directors being fit and proper persons.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the dual role of the Director of Bank Supervision in relation to the closure of a licensed commercial bank's branch, agency, or office?
test_cases.expected_output: The Director of Bank Supervision has a dual role in relation to the closure of a licensed commercial bank's branch, agency, or office. They are responsible for ensuring that all depositors are given the opportunity to withdraw their funds expeditiously and that measures are taken to safeguard their interests. Additionally, the Director is responsible for ensuring that the bank's closure is carried out in accordance with the law and that the bank's assets are distributed fairly among its creditors.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the restrictions on how a licensed commercial bank in Sri Lanka treats its subsidiary companies, and how does this relate to the bank's function?
test_cases.expected_output: A licensed commercial bank in Sri Lanka is not allowed to give its subsidiary companies better treatment than other bank constituents. According to the Monetary Board, a licensed commercial bank may have a subsidiary that engages in specific businesses, including training, hire purchase transactions, medium and long-term credit for development, factory leasing and warehousing, management consultancy services, or becoming a subsidiary due to the bank acquiring shares consequent to capitalizing interest accrued on loans granted by the bank. However, the bank cannot accord its subsidiary companies treatment that is more favorable than what is given to other constituents carrying on the same business. This ensures that the bank does not prioritize its subsidiaries over other customers, maintaining fairness in its functions.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the various aspects that the Monetary Board may investigate to ensure the suitability of a company or proposed company for a banking license, and what are the potential consequences of non-compliance?
test_cases.expected_output: The Monetary Board may investigate various aspects, including document validity, financial status, director and officer suitability, capital adequacy, liability coverage, and compliance with the Act. Non-compliance may result in the denial of a license or legal consequences under the Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the dual role of a licensed commercial bank's subsidiary concerning banking business, considering the Monetary Law Act and related sections?
test_cases.expected_output: A licensed commercial bank or licensed specialised bank shall not have as its subsidiary a company which is not a licensed commercial bank, as per section 17(1) of the Monetary Law Act. However, there are exceptions for certain associations, trade unions, and agencies. The subsidiary must be established in accordance with the Act and directions given.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the two main aspects that the Monetary Board considers while issuing a license to a commercial bank in Sri Lanka?
test_cases.expected_output: The Monetary Board considers two main aspects while issuing a license to a commercial bank in Sri Lanka: the suitability of the company or proposed company, and the ability of the company to remit money to Sri Lanka.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the dual purpose of equity share capital concerning dividends and capital distribution in a company?
test_cases.expected_output: Equity share capital serves a dual purpose by excluding any part of the issued share capital that does not carry the right to participate beyond a specified amount in dividends and capital distribution, as per the Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What criteria must be met for an individual or corporate body to be considered fit and proper persons to acquire a material interest in a licensed commercial bank in Sri Lanka?
test_cases.expected_output: The criteria for determining whether an individual or the directors of a corporate body are fit and proper persons are set out in subsection (2) of section 42 of the Monetary Law Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the conditions that must be met before a company can be issued a licence to carry on banking business, and what is the purpose of issuing a Letter of Provisional Approval?
test_cases.expected_output: A company must meet certain conditions before it can be issued a licence to carry on banking business, including being a public company with banking business as its primary object and restricting other forms of business it may carry on. The purpose of issuing a Letter of Provisional Approval is to enable the company or proposed company to proceed with preparations for commencing banking business, including raising capital, pending the issue of a licence under section 5.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the conditions that a licensed commercial bank must fulfill to reduce its equity capital, and what are the consequences of violating these conditions?
test_cases.expected_output: A licensed commercial bank cannot reduce its equity capital without the prior written approval of the Monetary Board. The Monetary Board may grant a reasonable period of time for the rectification of a deficiency in equity capital. Failure to comply with these requirements may result in the bank being unable to create any charge upon any unpaid capital, and any such charge created in contravention of these provisions shall be null and void.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the time frame within which the Monetary Board must consider objections under section 13(2), and what actions can the Board take after considering the objections?
test_cases.expected_output: The Monetary Board has 60 days to consider objections under section 13(2). After considering the objections, the Board can either cancel the notice of withdrawal or variation unconditionally or confirm the withdrawal or variation with or without modification, and direct the Director of Bank Supervision to take necessary steps to ensure that depositors are given the opportunity to withdraw their moneys expeditiously and that measures are taken to safeguard their interests.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the consequences for a licensed commercial bank that fails to comply with the capital requirements and restrictions on share holdings as specified in Part III of the Act?
test_cases.expected_output: A licensed commercial bank that fails to comply with the provisions of Part III of the Act shall be subject to penalties and other consequences as determined by the Monetary Board.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the consequences of a licensed commercial bank's licence being cancelled in Sri Lanka, considering its business both within and outside the country?
test_cases.expected_output: When a licensed commercial bank's licence is cancelled in Sri Lanka, it must suspend its business both within and outside the country. The Monetary Board will direct the bank to suspend its business and take charge of its assets, books, and records. The Director of Bank Supervision will take steps to prevent the continuation of the bank's business. If the bank is incorporated or established within Sri Lanka, proceedings for compulsory winding-up will begin. If the bank is incorporated outside Sri Lanka, the Director of Bank Supervision will inform the head office to honor its written undertaking and take steps to close down its business in and with respect to Sri Lanka.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the conditions that must be met for a licensed commercial bank to acquire the business or part of the business of another licensed commercial bank or a licensed specialised bank?
test_cases.expected_output: A licensed commercial bank can acquire the business or part of the business of another licensed commercial bank or a licensed specialised bank, but it requires the written approval of the Monetary Board with the concurrence of the Minister, and an application for approval must include a statement of the nature of the acquisition or merger or consolidation, as the case may be.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Under what circumstances can a licensed commercial bank appeal the Monetary Board's decision to cancel its license?
test_cases.expected_output: A licensed commercial bank can appeal the Monetary Board's decision to cancel its license to the Supreme Court, but only on a question of law.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the measures that the Monetary Board may take under section 11 of the Banking Act when a licensed commercial bank fails to comply with the requirements of the Monetary Board?
test_cases.expected_output: The Monetary Board may take several measures against a defaulting bank, including appointing an advisor, restraining directors or managers, assuming control, reorganizing the bank, amalgamating it with another bank, or vesting its business in another bank, all while ensuring that the measures do not preclude subsequent action under section 9 if deemed necessary for the banking system's interest.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the conditions under which the Monetary Board can delegate its powers to another person, and what are the purposes of such delegation?
test_cases.expected_output: The Monetary Board can delegate its powers to another person under section 11 of the Banking Act, specifically for the purposes of advising a bank on proper conduct, carrying on the business of a bank, or reorganizing a bank. The Board must give written notice of such delegation to the bank and any affected directors, managers, or controllers, and the delegation can be for a specified period or until further notice.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the circumstances under which the Monetary Board may cancel a licensed commercial bank's licence, considering the bank's business suspension and the Director of Bank Supervision's role?
test_cases.expected_output: The Monetary Board may cancel a licensed commercial bank's licence in any of the circumstances referred to in paragraphs (a) to (g) of subsection (1) of section 9, as per section 11(4) of the Act. The Monetary Board may direct the licensed commercial bank to suspend its business in Sri Lanka and outside Sri Lanka, and the Director of Bank Supervision shall take charge of its business and books, records, and assets, and take necessary steps to prevent the continuance of the banking business. Additionally, the Director of Bank Supervision shall inform the head office of the bank to honor the written undertaking submitted under paragraph (a) of subsection (2) of section 3 and take steps to enforce such undertaking and close down the bank's business in and with respect to Sri Lanka, according to Part VIII of this Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What dual role does the Monetary Board fulfill when issuing a license to a company concerning national economy and company suitability?
test_cases.expected_output: The Monetary Board conducts investigations before issuing a license to a company to satisfy itself as to the suitability of the company or proposed company to be issued with a license, having regard to the interests of the national economy, including the banking needs of Sri Lanka.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the restrictions on a licensed commercial bank's ability to create a charge on its unpaid capital, according to the Monetary Board's guidelines?
test_cases.expected_output: A licensed commercial bank is not allowed to create a charge on any unpaid capital, and any such charge created in contravention of these provisions shall be null and void, as per the Monetary Board's guidelines.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the dual role of the Monetary Board regarding licensed commercial banks in Sri Lanka, particularly in terms of subsidiaries and business engagements?
test_cases.expected_output: The Monetary Board ensures that licensed commercial banks in Sri Lanka do not have subsidiaries that are not licensed commercial banks and regulates the businesses that such banks can engage in, such as providing training, hire purchase transactions, medium and long-term credit, factory leasing and warehousing, management consultancy services, and more, as per the given context.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the circumstances under which a licensed commercial bank in Sri Lanka can tender objections to the Monetary Board regarding a notice of intended cancellation of its license?
test_cases.expected_output: A licensed commercial bank in Sri Lanka can tender objections in writing to the Monetary Board against the notice of intended cancellation within fourteen days of the date of receipt of such notice, giving reasons why the license issued to it under section 5 shall not be so cancelled.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the minimum equity capital requirement for a licensed commercial bank, as per the Act, considering the provisions for listed public companies, subsidiaries, and exceptions?
test_cases.expected_output: Every licensed commercial bank shall at all times maintain an equity capital in an amount not less than twenty-five million rupees or one hundred million rupees, depending on the date of issuance of the license, as per the Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the restrictions on the use of certain names and descriptions in relation to banking business in Sri Lanka, considering the exemptions for subsidiaries, trade unions, and representative offices of licensed commercial banks or specialized banks, as well as the requirement for prior written approval from the Monetary Board?
test_cases.expected_output: No company other than a licensed commercial bank or a licensed specialized bank shall use as part of its name or description any of the words 'bank', 'banker', or 'banking', or any of its derivatives or transliterations, or their equivalent in any other language, without the prior written approval of the Monetary Board, except for subsidiaries, trade unions, and representative offices of licensed commercial banks or specialized banks.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What dual role does the Monetary Board's power to cancel or confirm a notice of withdrawal or variation play in ensuring depositor protection and safe banking practices?
test_cases.expected_output: The Monetary Board's power to cancel or confirm a notice of withdrawal or variation plays a dual role in ensuring depositor protection and safe banking practices by safeguarding the interests of depositors and ensuring that banking business is carried on in a safe and sound manner.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Under what circumstances can a licensed commercial bank acquire shares in a public company other than a listed company?
test_cases.expected_output: A licensed commercial bank can acquire shares in a public company other than a listed company if it is necessary for the purpose of rehabilitating the company to make it financially viable.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What action does the Deputy Governor take after withdrawing or varying the terms and conditions of a mobile banking unit's approval?
test_cases.expected_output: The Deputy Governor communicates the decision to the relevant licensed commercial bank.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the circumstances under which the Monetary Board can cancel a license of a licensed commercial bank, and how does it affect the bank's operations?
test_cases.expected_output: The Monetary Board can cancel a license of a licensed commercial bank if it violates any provision of the Banking Act or any direction issued by the Monetary Board. If the license is canceled, the bank must stop its business operations, and the Director of Bank Supervision takes charge of its books, records, and assets. The Monetary Board may also issue directions to the bank to prohibit it from dealing with its assets, entering into transactions, or soliciting deposits.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What restrictions does the Monetary Board's direction have on a licensed commercial bank's legal action?
test_cases.expected_output: A licensed commercial bank cannot take legal action against the Monetary Board's directions, and any loss or damage resulting from such directions is not recoverable in court.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the conditions that a licensed commercial bank in Sri Lanka must fulfill to open or close a branch, agency, or office outside Sri Lanka?
test_cases.expected_output: A licensed commercial bank in Sri Lanka must obtain the written approval of the Monetary Board with the concurrence of the Minister to open or close a branch, agency, or office outside Sri Lanka.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Under what circumstances can a licensed commercial bank appeal the Monetary Board's decision to cancel its license, and what is the effect of cancellation?
test_cases.expected_output: A licensed commercial bank can appeal the Monetary Board's decision to cancel its license to the Court of Appeal within 14 days of receiving the notice of cancellation. The cancellation of a license takes effect from the date of receipt of the notification or upon confirmation of the decision by the Court of Appeal or Supreme Court, and the Monetary Board shall publish a notification of the cancellation in the Gazette and daily newspapers. The Monetary Board may also issue directions to the bank to prohibit it from dealing with assets, entering into transactions, or soliciting deposits, and failure to comply may result in the Director of Bank Supervision taking charge of the bank's business and assets.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the conditions for a licensed commercial bank or a licensed specialised bank to use a subsidiary to carry on banking business in Sri Lanka?
test_cases.expected_output: A licensed commercial bank or a licensed specialised bank can use a subsidiary to carry on banking business in Sri Lanka, subject to the approval of the Monetary Board, as per the provisions of the Monetary Law Act and the Finance Business Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Can the Monetary Board cancel a commercial bank's licence without suspending its business?
test_cases.expected_output: Yes, the Monetary Board can cancel a licensed commercial bank's licence without proceeding to suspend its business, as per section 11(4) of the Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the consequence if a licensed commercial bank doesn't start business within 9 months of getting the license?
test_cases.expected_output: If a licensed commercial bank fails to commence business within nine months of the issue of the license, the Monetary Board may give notice that it would cancel the license issued to such bank.

test_cases.prompt: Question: How is bank viability and national interest considered in setting minimum equity capital requirements for commercial banks?
test_cases.expected_output: The Monetary Board considers the viability and stability of the banking system and the interest of the national economy when determining the minimum equity capital requirement for a licensed commercial bank. The Board may vary the amount of equity capital required to be maintained by a bank, having regard to these factors.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What happens if you don't provide required documents?
test_cases.expected_output: Failing to furnish information or produce books, minutes, accounts, cash, securities, vouchers, other documents and records when required to do so is an offense under the Act and may be prima facie evidence of carrying on banking business without a license.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the process for a licensed commercial bank to open or close a branch?
test_cases.expected_output: The procedure for a licensed commercial bank to open or close a branch, agency, or office is to obtain the written approval of the Monetary Board with the concurrence of the Minister.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the point of a Banking Act license app?
test_cases.expected_output: The purpose of an application for a licence under the Banking Act is to obtain approval from the Monetary Board to carry on banking business in Sri Lanka.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the reason for suspending a bank's operations in Sri Lanka?
test_cases.expected_output: The purpose of the Monetary Board directing a licensed commercial bank to suspend its business in Sri Lanka is to prevent the continuance of the business of banking by such bank, as per the provisions of section 11(1) of the Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the impact of a license cancellation on a bank's ops?
test_cases.expected_output: The cancellation of a licensed commercial bank's license takes effect from the date of the receipt by the bank of the notification under subsection (8) of section 9, and the bank shall cease to carry on business in Sri Lanka.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Does a commercial bank need to tell its customers if its license is cancelled?
test_cases.expected_output: No, there is no provision in the Act that requires a licensed commercial bank to inform its customers when its licence has been cancelled.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the max foreign investment allowed in a Sri Lankan commercial bank?
test_cases.expected_output: The limit of foreign participation in the capital of a licensed commercial bank in Sri Lanka is established by the Monetary Board from time to time. The limit shall not exceed the amount established by the Board.

test_cases.prompt: Question: How does a commercial bank learn of a license cancellation?
test_cases.expected_output: The Monetary Board notifies a licensed commercial bank of its decision to cancel its license by issuing a notice in writing to the bank.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What does the Monetary Law Act grant the Monetary Board?
test_cases.expected_output: The powers conferred on the Monetary Board by section 30 of the Monetary Law Act include the power to approve or reject applications for licenses to carry on banking business, the power to revoke licenses, and the power to give directions to licensed banks.

test_cases.prompt: Question: How does a commercial bank's license get cancelled?
test_cases.expected_output: The Monetary Board notifies the public of a licensed commercial bank's cancellation of license by publishing a notification in the Gazette in Sinhala, Tamil, and English languages and once in a Sinhala, Tamil, and English daily newspaper circulating in Sri Lanka.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the legal framework for banking in Sri Lanka?
test_cases.expected_output: The Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What does the Act define as a holding company?
test_cases.expected_output: A company shall be deemed to be another's holding company if, and only if, that other is its subsidiary.

test_cases.prompt: Question: How is a commercial bank's capital adequacy ratio communicated?
test_cases.expected_output: The capital adequacy ratio of a licensed commercial bank is communicated to the bank in writing by the Monetary Board.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the impact on a foreign commercial bank's business in Sri Lanka when its license is revoked?
test_cases.expected_output: When the licence of a licensed commercial bank incorporated outside Sri Lanka is cancelled, the Director of Bank Supervision informs the head office of the bank to honour the written undertaking submitted under paragraph (a) of subsection (2) of section 3 and takes steps to enforce such undertaking and close down the business of the bank in and with respect to Sri Lanka, as per section 11(3) of the Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What happens to a commercial bank's assets and records when its license is reinstated?
test_cases.expected_output: When the Monetary Board withdraws the cancellation of a licensed commercial bank's license, it directs the Director of Bank Supervision to deliver forthwith to the bank the books, records, and assets taken into his custody.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the Director of Bank Supervision's role in canceling a commercial bank's license?
test_cases.expected_output: The Director of Bank Supervision takes charge of the business, books, records, and assets of a licensed commercial bank whose licence has been cancelled, as per section 11(1) of the Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the window for a commercial bank to contest a Monetary Board decision?
test_cases.expected_output: A licensed commercial bank has fourteen days from the date of receipt of the notification given under subsection (3) to appeal against a decision of the Monetary Board to the Court of Appeal.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the point of Part II of the Monetary Law Act?
test_cases.expected_output: The purpose of the provisions of Part II of the Monetary Law Act is to restrict the use of certain names and descriptions in relation to banking business in Sri Lanka.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the minimum capital requirement for a commercial bank in Sri Lanka?
test_cases.expected_output: The minimum amount of equity capital required for a licensed commercial bank in Sri Lanka is determined by the Monetary Board and may vary from time to time. The amount shall be prescribed in reference to the deposit liabilities, total liabilities, including contingent liabilities, total assets, or any specified category of assets of the bank.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the point of the subsection (7) exception?
test_cases.expected_output: The purpose of the proviso to subsection (7) is to ensure that the Monetary Board gives sufficient notice in writing to the applicant stating the grounds for withdrawal of the Letter of Provisional Approval or the decision to refrain from issuing a licence, and affords the applicant an opportunity of being heard before taking such action.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the minimum capital ratio for a commercial bank?
test_cases.expected_output: The minimum capital adequacy ratio that a licensed commercial bank must maintain is determined by the Monetary Board, which shall adopt the guidelines for capital adequacy set out by the Bank for International Settlements in Basle, as far as practicable.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the Monetary Board's subsection (10) power?
test_cases.expected_output: The Monetary Board may, at any time prior to the issue of a licence under section 5, conduct such investigations as it may deem necessary to satisfy itself as to the suitability of the company or proposed company to be issued with a licence, having regard to the interests of the national economy, including the banking needs of Sri Lanka.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's needed for a commercial bank license display?
test_cases.expected_output: Every licensed commercial bank shall display a copy of the license issued to it under subsection (1) in a conspicuous place at its principal place of business in Sri Lanka and each of its branches.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the meaning of "equity capital" under the Act?
test_cases.expected_output: Equity capital means paid up capital if it is a licensed commercial bank incorporated or established in Sri Lanka by or under any written law, or the amount assigned to such bank by the head office, if it is a licensed commercial bank incorporated or established outside Sri Lanka.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the process for a bank's liquidation?
test_cases.expected_output: The Director of Bank Supervision can terminate contracts during liquidation proceedings of a licensed commercial bank by issuing a notice to the affected parties, as stated in Section 61 of the Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Can a foreign company do banking business in Sri Lanka?
test_cases.expected_output: Yes, a company incorporated outside Sri Lanka can obtain a license, but it must comply with the provisions of Part XIII of the Companies Act No. 17 of 1982.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Can a commercial bank dispute a licence cancellation?
test_cases.expected_output: No, there is no provision in the Act for a licensed commercial bank to appeal against the Monetary Board's decision to cancel its licence.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the point of Schedule I in banking?
test_cases.expected_output: Schedule I to the Banking Act specifies the commercial banks that are exempt from the requirement of obtaining a license to carry on banking business.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What makes a company a subsidiary?
test_cases.expected_output: A company is considered a subsidiary of another company if the other company holds more than half of its equity share capital, controls the composition of its board of directors, or is a subsidiary of a company that is the subsidiary of the other company.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the minimum net profit amount that a licensed commercial bank must use for intangible assets?
test_cases.expected_output: An amount not less than twenty-five percent of the net profits of a licensed commercial bank shall be utilized for setting off intangible assets, as determined by the Monetary Board, before such profits are transferred to the reserve fund.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the impact of ignoring banking regulations?
test_cases.expected_output: Non-compliance with the provisions of the Banking Act may result in the company being guilty of an offense under the Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: How is a licensed commercial bank's equity capital computed?
test_cases.expected_output: The equity capital of a licensed commercial bank is computed by adding up the paid-up capital and the reserve fund of the bank. The reserve fund is created by transferring a portion of the bank's net profits each year, as determined by the Monetary Board.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's the process for winding up a commercial bank?
test_cases.expected_output: The procedure for the compulsory winding-up of a licensed commercial bank is as per the provisions of Part VIII of the Act, as mentioned in section 11(2) of the Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Can a commercial bank merge with another bank?
test_cases.expected_output: Yes, a licensed commercial bank can merge or consolidate with another licensed commercial bank or a licensed specialised bank, but it requires the written approval of the Monetary Board with the concurrence of the Minister.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What's needed for banking in Sri Lanka?
test_cases.expected_output: A company must obtain a license issued by the Monetary Board with the approval of the Minister.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the necessary steps that need to be taken by an applicant after receiving a Letter of Provisional Approval from the Monetary Board, and what is the time frame for completing these steps, and what happens if the applicant fails to comply with the requirements?
test_cases.expected_output: After receiving a Letter of Provisional Approval from the Monetary Board, the applicant must take all preliminary measures required in terms of the Letter prior to the issue of a licence under section 5. The applicant must also ensure that the period of validity of the Letter of Provisional Approval, which shall not exceed 12 months from the date of issue, is not expired. If the applicant fails to comply with the requirements, the Monetary Board may withdraw the Letter of Provisional Approval, and the applicant will have to reapply for a licence.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Suppose a licensed commercial bank is found to have violated the conditions for the grant of a loan by way of accommodation, and the Director of Bank Supervision has issued a direction to the bank to comply with the terms and conditions of the loan, and the bank has failed to comply. What is the priority of claims during the liquidation proceedings of the bank, considering the bank's failure to comply with the direction of the Director of Bank Supervision and the fact that the bank has sold its immovable property to a third party during the liquidation proceedings?
test_cases.expected_output: The priority of claims during the liquidation proceedings of the licensed commercial bank would be as follows: firstly, to pay off the depositors and creditors, and secondly, to pay off the expenses of the liquidation, as stated in Section 66 of the Act. However, considering the bank's failure to comply with the direction of the Director of Bank Supervision, the bank's assets that have been sold to a third party during the liquidation proceedings would not be included in the distribution of assets to creditors and depositors. Instead, those assets would be used to cover the expenses of the liquidation, and any remaining assets would be distributed to the creditors and depositors in accordance with the priority established in Section 66 of the Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the procedure to be followed by the Director of Bank Supervision when he is of the opinion that a licensed specialised bank is following unsound practices, and how does the Director ensure that the licensed specialised bank complies with the directions issued by him to rectify such practices, and what are the consequences if the licensed specialised bank fails to comply with such directions?
test_cases.expected_output: The Director of Bank Supervision, upon being of the opinion that a licensed specialised bank is following unsound practices, may issue directions to the bank to rectify such practices. The Director may also appoint an inspector to investigate the bank's practices and report back to him. If the bank fails to comply with the directions, the Director may revoke the bank's licence and take control of its assets and liabilities. The Director's decision is final and may not be appealed. The licensed specialised bank may, however, request the Monetary Board to review the Director's decision.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Considering the amendments to the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988, specifically Schedule II and IV, and the Monetary Law Act (Cap 422), what are the implications for a commercial bank that fails to comply with licensing requirements under the Banking Act?
test_cases.expected_output: According to the provided context, a commercial bank that fails to comply with licensing requirements under the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988, as amended by resolution 74/82 and 83/85, shall be guilty of an offense under the Act. Additionally, the bank shall be deemed to be an exempted company under the Companies Act, No. 17 of 1982, and shall not be subject to the Pawn Brokers Ordinance. Furthermore, the bank shall be considered an approved credit agency for the purposes of the Monetary Law Act (Cap 422).

test_cases.prompt: Question: What steps can the Director of Bank Supervision take to ensure that depositors' interests are safeguarded when a bank branch is closed, and how does this relate to the Deputy Governor's authority to grant approval for mobile banking units?
test_cases.expected_output: When a bank branch is closed, the Director of Bank Supervision can take steps to ensure that depositors' interests are safeguarded by directing the bank to allow depositors to withdraw their funds expeditiously and by taking measures to protect the depositors' money. The Director can also withdraw the approval granted to the bank for the establishment of mobile banking units if the bank fails to comply with the terms and conditions set by the Monetary Board. The Deputy Governor has the authority to grant approval for mobile banking units, but this authority is subject to the Director's power to withdraw approval if the bank fails to comply with regulations.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What specific steps must be taken by a company incorporated outside Sri Lanka to obtain a license to carry on banking business in Sri Lanka, considering the amendments made by resolution 74/82 and Acts 30 of 1988, 39 of 1990, 33 of 1995, 2 of 2005, 15 of 2006, and 46 of 2006, and how does Schedule II and IV to the Banking Act No. 30 of 1988, as amended, apply to such a company?
test_cases.expected_output: A company incorporated outside Sri Lanka must comply with the provisions of Part XIII of the Companies Act No. 17 of 1982 and obtain the approval of the Minister in order to obtain a license to carry on banking business in Sri Lanka. Schedule II and IV to the Banking Act No. 30 of 1988, as amended, apply to such a company, and the company must also comply with the requirements of section 2(2) and (3) of the Banking Act No. 30 of 1988, as amended, and section 449 of the Companies Act No. 17 of 1982.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the limits imposed on all licensed commercial banks in Sri Lanka, and how are they determined?
test_cases.expected_output: The limits imposed on all licensed commercial banks in Sri Lanka are determined by the Monetary Board, which has the authority to set limits on the different classes of banking business carried on by such banks. The Monetary Board takes into account the nature and scope of the banking business, the bank's financial position, and any other relevant factors when determining the limits. The limits may include restrictions on the bank's lending and investment activities, as well as requirements for capital adequacy and liquidity. The Monetary Board may also impose additional requirements or restrictions on individual banks based on their specific circumstances.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the significance of September 16th, 1988, in relation to the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988, and how does it relate to the licensing of commercial banks in Sri Lanka?
test_cases.expected_output: September 16th, 1988, is significant in relation to the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988, as it marks the date when the provisions of the Act, other than Part V, came into operation. This means that on this date, the Act began to regulate the licensing of commercial banks in Sri Lanka, as per the provisions of Part I of the Act. The licensing of commercial banks is important because it ensures that only authorized entities are allowed to carry on banking business in Sri Lanka, thereby maintaining the stability and integrity of the financial system in the country.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the significance of the phrase 'a body corporate established by or under any written law' in the definition of 'company' in the Banking Act, and how does it relate to the licensing of commercial banks in Sri Lanka?
test_cases.expected_output: The phrase 'a body corporate established by or under any written law' in the definition of 'company' in the Banking Act includes any corporate entity established under a statute or regulation, such as a government-owned corporation or a public-private partnership. This phrase is significant because it allows for the licensing of commercial banks that are not necessarily private companies, but are still subject to the regulations and oversight of the Monetary Board. In Sri Lanka, commercial banks are required to obtain a license from the Monetary Board in order to operate legally, and the definition of 'company' in the Banking Act ensures that all entities that carry on banking business, including those established under written law, are subject to the same regulatory framework.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What steps must an applicant take after receiving a Letter of Provisional Approval, and how does the Monetary Board ensure that the applicant is qualified to proceed with the licensing process?
test_cases.expected_output: After receiving a Letter of Provisional Approval, the applicant must take all preliminary measures required in terms of the Letter, such as submitting additional documents and information, undergoing further investigations, and meeting with regulatory requirements. The Monetary Board ensures that the applicant is qualified to proceed with the licensing process by conducting thorough investigations and evaluating the applicant's ability to meet the requirements set out in the Letter of Provisional Approval and the relevant laws and regulations.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the implications of Schedule II to this Act for a company seeking to obtain a licence to carry on banking business, and how does the Monetary Board ensure that the company complies with the requirements of the Act before issuing a licence?
test_cases.expected_output: Schedule II to this Act restricts the forms of business that a company may carry on, other than banking business, if it is to be issued a licence under section 5. The Monetary Board ensures that the company complies with the requirements of the Act before issuing a licence by conducting investigations as necessary to satisfy itself as to the suitability of the company or proposed company to be issued with a licence, having regard to the interests of the national economy, including the banking needs of Sri Lanka. The Monetary Board may also withdraw a Letter of Provisional Approval or refrain from issuing a licence if the company or proposed company has not complied with the conditions stipulated in the Letter of Provisional Approval, has not complied with the requirements under this Act for the issue of a licence, or has provided false or incorrect information in its application or supporting documents. Additionally, the Monetary Board may not issue a licence if there has been a sufficiently significant change in the economic and banking environment of the country that warrants the suspension of the issue of licence under section 5.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Suppose a licensed commercial bank wants to establish a mobile banking unit. What steps must be taken by the bank and the Monetary Board to ensure compliance with the law?
test_cases.expected_output: The bank must first obtain approval from the Deputy Governor by guidelines issued by the Monetary Board for such purpose. The Deputy Governor may grant approval subject to such terms and conditions as he may determine. The Monetary Board shall direct the Director of Bank Supervision to take all steps as may appear necessary in the circumstances to ensure that all persons who have deposited moneys in that branch, agency, or office are given the opportunity to withdraw such moneys expeditiously and to ensure that such measures as would safeguard the interest of such depositors are taken. The Director of Bank Supervision may require the bank to furnish information or produce books, accounts, and records for inspection to ensure compliance with the law.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What measures should be taken by the Director of Bank Supervision when dealing with a licensed commercial bank that has been found to be engaging in unsound practices, and how does this relate to the handling of safe deposit boxes during liquidation proceedings?
test_cases.expected_output: When the Director of Bank Supervision determines that a licensed commercial bank is engaging in unsound practices, they have the authority to take control of the bank's management and operations, as stated in Section 58 of the Act. This includes the power to terminate contracts and fiduciary functions, as well as the ability to issue directions in respect of connected matters. In the event that liquidation proceedings are instituted, the Director of Bank Supervision is responsible for safeguarding the rights of depositors and creditors, as stated in Section 54 of the Act. This includes ensuring that safe deposit boxes are not affected during the liquidation process, as stated in Section 63 of the Act. Therefore, the Director of Bank Supervision must take appropriate measures to address any unsound practices by a licensed commercial bank while also ensuring that safe deposit boxes are protected during any subsequent liquidation proceedings.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What is the maximum percentage of capital funds that a licensed commercial bank can invest in the shares of a listed public company, and how is this percentage determined?
test_cases.expected_output: The maximum percentage of capital funds that a licensed commercial bank can invest in the shares of a listed public company is determined by the Monetary Board and is currently set at 50% or less. However, this limit can be exceeded if the acquisition of shares becomes necessary for the purpose of rehabilitating a financially viable company, in which case the bank must dispose of the excess shares within two years or a longer period determined by the Monetary Board.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the consequences for a licensed commercial bank that fails to comply with the provisions of section 6, and how does the Monetary Board address such non-compliance?
test_cases.expected_output: If a licensed commercial bank fails to comply with the provisions of section 6, the Monetary Board may cancel its license after providing notice and considering objections from the bank. The bank may also be subject to conditions imposed by the Monetary Board, and may appeal the decision to the Court of Appeal. The Monetary Board's decision to cancel a license may be influenced by factors such as the bank's failure to commence business within nine months of the issue of the license, failure to pay debts, appointment of a liquidator or receiver, cessation of banking business, contravention of the Act or directions, furnishing false information, carrying on business in a detrimental manner, or failure to comply with conditions imposed by the Monetary Board.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Suppose a licensed commercial bank's licence is cancelled due to a breach of the written undertaking submitted under paragraph (a) of subsection (2) of section 3. What steps will the Director of Bank Supervision take to enforce the undertaking and close down the bank's business in and with respect to Sri Lanka?
test_cases.expected_output: The Director of Bank Supervision will first inform the head office of the bank to honour the written undertaking submitted under paragraph (a) of subsection (2) of section 3. Then, the Director will take such steps as may be necessary to enforce such undertaking and close down the bank's business in and with respect to Sri Lanka, in accordance with the provisions of Part VIII of this Act. This may include directing the bank to suspend its business in Sri Lanka and outside Sri Lanka, taking charge of its business, books, records, and assets, and commencing proceedings for the compulsory winding-up of the bank, all as per the provisions of section 11(3) and Part VIII of the Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What measures can be taken by the Director of Bank Supervision in case of insolvency of a licensed specialised bank, and how does the Central Bank ensure that the licensed specialised bank maintains the required capital, and what is the procedure for the winding-up or dissolution of a licensed specialised bank?
test_cases.expected_output: In case of insolvency of a licensed specialised bank, the Director of Bank Supervision can take measures such as issuing directions to the bank, appointing an administrator, and vesting the business of the bank in another licensed bank. The Central Bank ensures that the licensed specialised bank maintains the required capital by monitoring their financial statements and enforcing the capital adequacy requirements. The procedure for the winding-up or dissolution of a licensed specialised bank involves the Director of Bank Supervision filing a petition in court, and the court appointing a liquidator to manage the winding-up process.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What measures can be taken by the Director of Bank Supervision to ensure that the rights of depositors and creditors are safeguarded during the liquidation process of a licensed commercial bank, and how are unclaimed funds handled in this process?
test_cases.expected_output: The Director of Bank Supervision can take several measures to safeguard the rights of depositors and creditors during the liquidation process of a licensed commercial bank, as stated in Sections 51-69 of the Act. These measures include sending notices to depositors, creditors, and other relevant parties, terminating contracts, and ensuring that the licensed commercial bank ceases to carry on business. Unclaimed funds during liquidation proceedings are transferred to a special account, and the Director of Bank Supervision is responsible for their safekeeping, as stated in Section 68 of the Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What measures can be taken by the Director of Bank Supervision when they suspect that a licensed specialised bank is engaging in unsound practices, and how does the Monetary Board's issuance of directions to licensed specialised banks factor into this process?
test_cases.expected_output: When the Director of Bank Supervision suspects that a licensed specialised bank is engaging in unsound practices, they can examine the bank's books and accounts, issue directions to the bank to rectify the situation, and, if necessary, initiate liquidation proceedings. The Monetary Board's issuance of directions to licensed specialised banks provides guidance and ensures that these banks maintain sound practices and comply with the requirements of the Act, which helps prevent unsound practices and protect depositors' interests.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Can a licensed commercial bank incorporated or established in Sri Lanka have a subsidiary that is not a licensed commercial bank, and if so, what are the conditions that must be met?
test_cases.expected_output: A licensed commercial bank incorporated or established in Sri Lanka can have a subsidiary that is not a licensed commercial bank, but only with the written permission of the Monetary Board. The subsidiary must carry on any one or more of the following businesses: providing training in subjects relating to banking, accountancy, valuation, project appraisal, and credit appraisal; engaging in hire purchase transactions; providing medium and long-term credit for development; factory leasing and warehousing; providing management consultancy services; becoming the subsidiary only by reason of a licensed commercial bank having to acquire the share of a company consequent to such licensed commercial bank capitalizing the capital and the interest accrued thereon and which is unpaid by the company to the bank, on loans granted by the licensed commercial bank; or carrying on any form of business which in the opinion of the Monetary Board is not inconsistent with the business of banking and the provision of finance. Additionally, the licensed commercial bank shall not accord to any of its subsidiary companies treatment that is more favourable than the treatment accorded to other constituents of the bank carrying on the same business as any such subsidiary company.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the necessary steps that an applicant must take to obtain a license to carry on banking business in Sri Lanka, and what is the significance of a Letter of Provisional Approval in this process?
test_cases.expected_output: To obtain a license to carry on banking business in Sri Lanka, an applicant must first submit an application in writing to the Monetary Board, accompanied by various documents such as the draft Articles of Association or Constitution, a statement containing the names and qualifications of proposed Directors and Chief Executive Officer, audited balance sheet and profit and loss account for the preceding three years, and a written undertaking supported by a resolution of the Board of Directors if the company is incorporated outside Sri Lanka. The Director of Bank Supervision may also require additional documents or information to determine whether a license should be issued. If the Monetary Board is satisfied that the application may be approved in principle, it will issue a Letter of Provisional Approval, which requires the applicant to take all preliminary measures specified in the Letter prior to the issue of a license under section 5. The Letter of Provisional Approval is valid for a specified period, usually not exceeding twelve months, and may be extended in exceptional circumstances. The Monetary Board will send a copy of the Letter of Provisional Approval and any communication extending its validity or withdrawing it to the Registrar of Companies.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the necessary steps that must be taken to obtain a license for a banking business in Sri Lanka, considering the amendments made by resolution 74/82, 82A, 83, 83B, 84, 85, and 86, and the interpretations provided in Schedule I, II, III, and IV of the Banking Act No. 30 of 1988, as well as the relevant provisions of the Companies Act No. 17 of 1982, and how does one ensure that the application is made in accordance with the provisions of this Act?
test_cases.expected_output: To obtain a license for a banking business in Sri Lanka, one must first determine if the company is a licensed commercial bank deemed to be an approved credit agency, as per section 83A of the Banking Act No. 30 of 1988. If not, the company must comply with the provisions of Part XIII of the Companies Act No. 17 of 1982. The application for a license shall be made in writing to the Monetary Board in such manner as may be determined by the Monetary Board, as per section 3 of the Banking Act No. 30 of 1988. Additionally, the application must be made in accordance with the interpretations provided in Schedule I, II, III, and IV of the Banking Act No. 30 of 1988. Furthermore, the company must ensure that it complies with the provisions of the Pawn Brokers Ordinance and the Monetary Law Act (Cap 422), as per section 83B and 85 of the Banking Act No. 30 of 1988. Finally, the company must ensure that the application is made on or after the appointed date, as per section 2(1) of the Banking Act No. 30 of 1988.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What documents should a company incorporated outside Sri Lanka submit in addition to the documents specified in paragraph (b) when making an application for a licence?
test_cases.expected_output: {'documents': ['a written undertaking supported by a resolution of the Board of Directors of such company or body corporate, stating that such company or body corporate, as the case may be, shall on demand by the Central Bank, provide such funds as may be necessary to meet all obligations incurred in or in connection with, its business in Sri Lanka', 'a report containing such information as may be determined by the Monetary Board, from the regulatory authority of the country in which such company or body corporate is incorporated'], 'additional_info': ['The company shall also provide a copy of the audited balance sheet and profit and loss account of the company for the preceding three years', 'The Monetary Board may require the applicant to furnish additional documents, information or other particulars to determine whether a licence shall be issued or not']}

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the consequences for a licensed commercial bank that fails to comply with the directions given by the Monetary Board under Section 46 of the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988, when it comes to the bank's ability to remit currency to Sri Lanka?
test_cases.expected_output: If a licensed commercial bank fails to comply with the directions given by the Monetary Board under Section 46 of the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988, the bank may face consequences such as suspension of business, cancellation of its licence, or variation of its approval to carry on banking business. Additionally, the bank may also be subject to penalties or fines as determined by the Monetary Board. This could ultimately affect the bank's ability to remit currency to Sri Lanka.
