test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the consequences for a licensed commercial bank that fails to comply with the directions given by the Monetary Board under Section 46 of the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988, when engaging in off-shore banking business, and how does the Monetary Board specify the form of balance sheet and profit and loss account for off-shore banking business, and what is the nature of business that an off-shore unit is authorized to carry on, and how does the Monetary Board authorize off-shore banking business, and what is the procedure for preparing and publishing balance sheet and profit and loss accounts, and what are the powers of the Director of Bank Supervision over off-shore units, and what are the consequences of failure to submit an audit report, and how does the Monetary Board cause examination of a licensed commercial bank or any of its subsidiaries, and what are the qualifications for being appointed or elected as a director of a licensed commercial bank, and what is the role of the Secretary of a licensed commercial bank, and what are the powers of the Director of Bank Supervision, and how does the Monetary Board give directions to licensed commercial banks, and what are the conditions for the grant of a loan by way of accommodation, and what are the prohibitions in the sale, transfer, &c., of immovable assets, and what happens in case of insolvency, and how does the Monetary Board vest the banking business of any licensed bank?
test_cases.expected_output: A licensed commercial bank that fails to comply with the directions given by the Monetary Board under Section 46 of the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988, when engaging in off-shore banking business, may face consequences such as suspension or cancellation of its license. The Monetary Board specifies the form of balance sheet and profit and loss account for off-shore banking business under Section 28. The nature of business that an off-shore unit is authorized to carry on is specified under Section 25. The Monetary Board authorizes off-shore banking business under Section 23. The procedure for preparing and publishing balance sheet and profit and loss accounts is outlined under Sections 33-38. The Director of Bank Supervision has powers over off-shore units under Section 34. Failure to submit an audit report may result in consequences such as cancellation of the license. The Monetary Board causes examination of a licensed commercial bank or any of its subsidiaries under Section 41. Qualifications for being appointed or elected as a director of a licensed commercial bank are outlined under Section 42. The role of the Secretary of a licensed commercial bank is outlined under Section 43. The powers of the Director of Bank Supervision are outlined under Section 45. The Monetary Board gives directions to licensed commercial banks under Section 46. Conditions for the grant of a loan by way of accommodation are outlined under Section 47. Prohibitions in the sale, transfer, &c., of immovable assets are outlined under Section 49. In case of insolvency, the Monetary Board may vest the banking business of any licensed bank under Section 49B.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Suppose a company, XYZ Inc., incorporated outside Sri Lanka, wants to remit currency to Sri Lanka and carry on banking business in the country. What are the requirements and procedures that XYZ Inc. needs to follow to obtain a licence to carry on banking business in Sri Lanka, and what are the consequences if it fails to comply with the requirements?
test_cases.expected_output: {'steps': [{'step': 'XYZ Inc. must first incorporate itself in Sri Lanka as a subsidiary of the parent company, XYZ Group, in accordance with the Companies Act, No. 7 of 2007.', 'reference': 'Section 4 of the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988'}, {'step': 'XYZ Inc. must then apply for a licence to carry on banking business in Sri Lanka by submitting an application to the Monetary Board, along with the required documents and information, including its incorporation certificate, memorandum and articles of association, and details of its directors and management team.', 'reference': 'Section 3 of the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988'}, {'step': "The Monetary Board will then review XYZ Inc.'s application and may request additional information or clarification, if necessary. If the application is deemed complete and satisfactory, the Monetary Board will issue a licence to XYZ Inc. to carry on banking business in Sri Lanka.", 'reference': 'Section 5 of the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988'}, {'step': 'If XYZ Inc. fails to comply with the requirements for obtaining a licence or violates any of the conditions of its licence, it may face penalties, including fines, suspension or revocation of its licence, or other legal action, as determined by the Monetary Board.', 'reference': 'Sections 10, 11, and 46 of the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988'}], 'notes': [{'note': "The Monetary Board may also impose additional requirements or conditions on XYZ Inc.'s licence, based on its assessment of the company's fitness and propriety to carry on banking business in Sri Lanka.", 'reference': 'Section 3(3) of the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988'}, {'note': 'XYZ Inc. must also comply with ongoing regulatory requirements, including maintaining minimum capital and liquidity ratios, submitting periodic returns and reports, and adhering to anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing regulations.', 'reference': 'Parts III, V, and VI of the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988'}]}

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the requirements for a licensed commercial bank to engage in off-shore banking business in Sri Lanka, and what are the consequences of failure to comply with these requirements? Also, what is the procedure for the Monetary Board to authorize off-shore banking business, and what are the powers of the Director of Bank Supervision over off-shore units?
test_cases.expected_output: A licensed commercial bank in Sri Lanka must comply with the provisions of Part III of the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988, which includes obtaining a license from the Monetary Board, maintaining a minimum capital requirement, and complying with liquidity and reserve requirements. Failure to comply with these requirements may result in the cancellation of the bank's license. The Monetary Board must authorize off-shore banking business in accordance with Section 23 of the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988. The Director of Bank Supervision has the power to cause examinations of off-shore units and to issue directions to ensure compliance with the Act. The Director also maintains a list of qualified auditors for the purpose of auditing off-shore units.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the consequences for a licensed specialised bank that fails to maintain the minimum capital requirement as per Section 76G of the Act, and how does the Director of Bank Supervision determine the adequacy of the bank's capital, and what powers does the Director have to address any non-compliance, and how does the bank's failure to comply with the directions of the Monetary Board impact its ability to carry on banking business, and what actions can the Director take to enforce compliance, and what are the implications for the bank's customers and creditors, and how does the law protect them in such a scenario?
test_cases.expected_output: If a licensed specialised bank fails to maintain the minimum capital requirement as per Section 76G of the Act, the Director of Bank Supervision can examine its books and accounts and take appropriate action, as stated in Section 76K of the Act. The Director can also issue directions to the bank to increase its capital or take other measures to address the non-compliance. If the bank fails to comply with the Director's directions, the Director can take further action, including appointing an administrator to take control of the bank's business, as per Section 76L. The bank's failure to comply with the directions of the Monetary Board can impact its ability to carry on banking business, and the Director can take steps to restrict or revoke its licence. The law protects the bank's customers and creditors by providing for the continuation of the bank's operations under the control of an administrator, and ensuring that their interests are safeguarded in the event of the bank's liquidation, as per Sections 76M and 76N. The customers and creditors can also file claims with the liquidator, as per Section 66, and the bank's assets are distributed in accordance with the priority of claims, as per Section 67.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What measures must a licensed commercial bank take to ensure that it has sufficient liquid assets to meet the requirements of its reserve fund, given that the Monetary Board may impose specific provisions on requirements for bad and doubtful debts, and the bank must also comply with the directions of the Director of Bank Supervision regarding the preparation of its balance sheet and profit and loss account, and the bank's capital must not be less than the prescribed minimum, and the bank must also maintain a reserve fund equal to 25% of its deposit liabilities, and the bank must also comply with the restrictions on the use of certain names and descriptions, and the bank must also have its accounts audited annually by a qualified auditor, and the bank must also publish its balance sheet and profit and loss account, and the bank must also comply with the power of the Monetary Board to call for information, and the bank must also comply with the power of the Director of Bank Supervision to cause examination of the bank's books and accounts, and the bank must also comply with the requirements for the preparation of its annual report, and the bank must also comply with the restrictions on the sale, transfer, &c., of immovable assets, and the bank must also inform the Director of Bank Supervision in case of insolvency, and the bank must also comply with the order vesting the banking business of any licensed bank?
test_cases.expected_output: To ensure that a licensed commercial bank has sufficient liquid assets to meet the requirements of its reserve fund, the bank must comply with a range of regulations and requirements set out in the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988, as amended. The bank must maintain a reserve fund equal to 25% of its deposit liabilities, and must also comply with the directions of the Director of Bank Supervision regarding the preparation of its balance sheet and profit and loss account. The bank's capital must not be less than the prescribed minimum, and the bank must also comply with the restrictions on the use of certain names and descriptions. The bank must also have its accounts audited annually by a qualified auditor, and must publish its balance sheet and profit and loss account. The bank must also comply with the power of the Monetary Board to call for information, and the power of the Director of Bank Supervision to cause examination of the bank's books and accounts. The bank must also comply with the requirements for the preparation of its annual report, and the restrictions on the sale, transfer, &c., of immovable assets. In case of insolvency, the bank must inform the Director of Bank Supervision, and must also comply with any order vesting the banking business of any licensed bank. By complying with these regulations and requirements, the bank can ensure that it has sufficient liquid assets to meet the requirements of its reserve fund.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the specific requirements that a licensed commercial bank must fulfill in order to engage in off-shore banking business, and how does the Monetary Board ensure that these requirements are met?
test_cases.expected_output: According to Section 23 of the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988, a licensed commercial bank can engage in off-shore banking business with the approval of the Monetary Board. The Monetary Board has the authority to specify the form of balance sheet and profit and loss account that an off-shore unit of a licensed commercial bank is required to prepare, as well as to authorize off-shore banking business in certain circumstances. Additionally, the Monetary Board has the power to call for information from a licensed commercial bank and to cause examination of the bank's off-shore unit. The Director of Bank Supervision also has the power to issue a list of qualified auditors for the purpose of auditing the off-shore unit. Furthermore, the licensed commercial bank must comply with the provisions of Parts III, V, and VI of the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988, and must maintain books, accounts, and prepare balance sheets and profit and loss accounts in the prescribed form. The Monetary Board may also impose general and specific provisions on requirements for bad and doubtful debts, and may prohibit a licensed commercial bank from engaging in certain activities such as buying, selling, or transferring immovable property.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Suppose a licensed commercial bank, XYZ Bank, fails to commence business within the time specified in its licence. What are the potential consequences for XYZ Bank, and what steps can the Monetary Board take in this scenario?
test_cases.expected_output: If XYZ Bank fails to commence business within the time specified in its licence, the Monetary Board may cancel the licence and impose a penalty on the bank, as per Section 9 of the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988. Additionally, the Monetary Board may also take steps to recover any losses incurred by the bank during the period it was operating without a licence. The Monetary Board may also impose restrictions on the bank's operations or appoint a special manager to manage the bank's affairs. Furthermore, the bank's directors and officers may face disqualification or other penalties for violating the Banking Act. The Monetary Board may also take into account the bank's failure to commence business when considering future applications for licences or approvals.

test_cases.prompt: Question: Suppose a licensed commercial bank has been ordered to be wound up by the court and its assets have been vested in the Central Bank. Can the Central Bank sell or transfer the bank's immovable assets to a third party, considering the prohibition on dealing with immovable property in Section 45 of the Act?
test_cases.expected_output: Yes, the Central Bank can sell or transfer the immovable assets of the wound-up licensed commercial bank to a third party. According to Section 49A of the Act, the prohibition on dealing with immovable property in Section 45 does not apply to the Central Bank when it is acting as a liquidator of a licensed commercial bank. Therefore, the Central Bank can sell or transfer the immovable assets of the wound-up bank in accordance with the provisions of the Act.

test_cases.prompt: Question: What are the consequences for a licensed commercial bank that fails to maintain the minimum capital requirement as stipulated in Section 20 of the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988?
test_cases.expected_output: If a licensed commercial bank fails to maintain the minimum capital requirement as stipulated in Section 20 of the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988, it may face consequences such as being directed by the Monetary Board to suspend business, having its license cancelled, or being subject to disciplinary action, as per Section 40 of the Banking Act, No. 30 of 1988.
